item.title: Propositions and Connectives, Truth Table
item.description: Definition 1 A statement that is either true or false is called a proposition. A proposition has one of two truth values, either true or false. If two propositions $p$, $q$ have the same truth value, $p$ and $q$ are said to be (logically) equivalent, and this is expressed as $p \equiv q$. As a method to construct composite propositions, the following symbols are called connectives: Negation: $\lnot$ Conjunction: $\land$
